source.title: Malva
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae

leads.lead_text: Lobes of epicalyx fused to each other; erect,  often tall herbs or soft-wooded shrubs
Lobes of epicalyx free from each other (but often adnate to calyx tube); low, sometimes prostrate herbs
Epicalyx remaining shorter than calyx, not much enlarged in fruit; flowers pale, bluish, pink or white; spreading to erect shrubs, but rarely exceeding 1.5 m
Epicalyx exceeding calyx, enlarging further and spreading in fruit; flowers bright magenta to purple; ± erect shrub to c. 3 m high, chiefly coastal
Petals 10–18 mm long; epicalyx at least two-thirds as long as calyx at anthesis; mericarps smooth dorsally, adjacent angles usually rounded
Petals 15–30 mm long; epicalyx less than two-thirds as long as calyx at anthesis; mericarps reticulate, adjacent angles acute, sometimes narrowly winged, usually dentate
Flowers lilac or pink; leaves well-spaced along stems, yellowish-green, paler and usually distinctly more densely pubescent below; inland
Flowers white except for mauve veins; leaves crowded on stems, grey-green or dark green, both surfaces more or less equally stellate pubescent; coastal
Leaves ± entire or broadly and shallowly lobed; lower flowers clustered in axils; mericarps often ridged or wrinkled
Upper leaves deeply incised and narrowly lobed; lower flowers solitary in axils; mericarps densely hispid but not ridged or wrinkled
Mature mericarps virtually flat dorsally, prominently ridged, wrinkled or reticulate
Mature mericarps dorsally rounded, smooth beneath the fine pubescence
Corolla conspicuously exceeding calyx; fruiting calyx not significantly enlarged, the lobes incurved over mericarps; adjacent margins of mericarps not raised, ± smooth
Corolla not or barely exceeding calyx; fruiting calyx considerably enlarged, the lobes recurving to reveal mericarps; adjacent margins of mericarps usually raised and ± toothed
Corolla 6–12 mm long, not more than 2.5 times as long as sepals
Corolla 12–30 mm long or more, 3–4 times as long as sepals
